Fig. 1 Crystal structures of a) CuNbO3, b) CuNb13O33, c) CuNb3O8, d) monoclinic CuNb2O6, e) orthorhombic CuNb2O6, f) Cu3Nb2O8 and g) Cu2Nb34O87. Nb: blue, Cu: green, mixed Cu/Nb sites: turquoise and O: red. Structures have been drawn based on data depicted and referenced in Table 1. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 Scheme of reaction vessels for molten salt reaction. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 Rietveld refinements of a) CuNbO3 after annealing at 900 C° for 24 h, b) CuNb3O8 after annealing at 750 °C for 1 h, c) CuNb13O33 after annealing at 900 °C for 10 h, d) monoclinic CuNb2O6 after annealing at 800 °C for 10 h, e) orthorhombic CuNb2O6 after annealing at 1000 °C for 20 h and f) Cu3Nb2O8 after annealing at 950 °C for 10 h. The insets show a magnification of the refinement at higher angles. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 Overview of a) Nb−O and b) Cu−O distances obtained via Rietveld refinement and c) bond valence sums calculated from a) and b); (s): square planar, (p): square pyramidal. Identical distances that occur twice are marked with a 2, whereas highly similar, but non-identical distances are circled. Vertical lines in a) mark the border between the different Nb atoms and are meant to guide the eye. The horizontal lines in b) mark the Cu−O distances for Cu2O and CuO,[54,55] whereas the lines in c) mark the theoretically expected values. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 SEM images of copper niobates. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 Results of mercury intrusion porosimetry for macroporous samples: a) cumulative pore volumes and b) pore size distributions. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 a) Kubelka-Munk absorption spectra with determined optical band gaps; the difference of the signal noise stems from a detector change of the instrument at 860 nm, b) Raman spectra of copper niobates, c) normalised Mott-Schottky plots measured at 10 Hz and d) scheme of estimated band positions and comparison with literature values, taken from references[10,14,28,57] and re-calculated for RHE and pH = 0 if necessary. In red the oxidation potential of methanol is shown. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 High-resolution XP spectra of a) Cu 2p 3/2, b) Cu L3M45M45, c) Wagner Plot, d) Nb 3d and e) O 1 s regions of copper niobates. Fig. 8 Fig. 9 X-ray diffraction patterns of a) CuNbO3 and b) monoclinic CuNb2O6 after stirring for one week in the respective solvent. Additionally, CuNb2O6 was also measured after 6 months storage of the powder under ambient conditions. Fig. 9 Fig. 10 Hydrogen evolution rates of copper niobates in water/methanol under irradiation from a) Xe lamp and b) ultraviolet light from a Hg lamp. The arrows in a) indicate the time when an additional 420 nm filter was inserted into the beam path to remove the UV light from the lamp spectra. Fig. 10 Fig. 11 a) High-resolution Cu 2p 3/2 XP spectrum after photocatalysis and b) ratios of copper oxidation states, Nb defects and O 1 s defects before and after photocatalysis in UV light. Table 3 material CuNbO3 CuNb3O8 CuNb13O33 CuNb2O6 CuNb2O6 Cu3Nb2O8 space group C2/m P2 1 /a C2/m P2 1 /c Pbcn P 1 ̅ a / Å 9.491 15.372 22.544 5.006 14.112 5.182 b / Å 8.440 5.074 3.827 14.177 5.611 5.483 c / Å 6.765 7.529 15.417 5.762 5.127 6.011 α / ° 90 90 90 90 90 72.54 β / ° 90.87 107.17 91.26 91.73 90 83.41 γ / ° 90 90 90 90 90 65.68 V / Å3 541.8 561.1 1329.9 408.8 406.0 148.5 Syntheses and characterisation of p-type copper niobium oxides for photocatalytic hydrogen generation Morten Weiss Roland Marschall ⁎ 1 Department of Chemistry, University of Bayreuth, Universitaetsstr. 30, 95440 Bayreuth, Germany Department of Chemistry, University of Bayreuth Universitaetsstr. 30 Bayreuth 95440 Germany Department of Chemistry, University of Bayreuth, Universitaetsstr. 30, 95440 Bayreuth, Germany ⁎ Corresponding author. 1 ORCID: 0000-0002-1057-0459 Copper niobium oxides have small band gaps and can absorb visible light, making these materials promising for semiconductor photocatalysis. Their chemical stability also greatly surpasses those of the binary copper oxides, which are prone to photocorrosion. Herein, we thoroughly investigate the material system Cu-Nb-O and synthesise up to six different phase-pure and highly crystalline oxides: CuNbO3, CuNb13O33, CuNb3O8, monoclinic and orthorhombic CuNb2O6, and Cu3Nb2O8. Synthesis conditions have been optimised towards easier and more economic syntheses compared to known literature procedures, and all materials were thoroughly analysed with respect to optical and electronic properties and their chemical stability. All materials are utilised in photocatalytic hydrogen evolution, with a heterojunction of monoclinic and orthorhombic CuNb2O6 being the most active one. Graphical Abstract A systematic investigation into syntheses and properties of semiconducting copper niobates CuxNbyOz and their photocatalytic activities. ga1 Keywords Copper niobium oxides Photocatalysis Hydrogen generation Visible light absorption Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The ever-growing energy demand is arguably one of the greatest problems of our time,[1] especially as the world energy consumption is projected to increase further [2]. Solar energy is a near-infinite energy source able to satisfy this demand many times over,[2] however, it is subject to fluctuations on daily, seasonal, an regional basis, as well as dependent on weather. Photocatalysis is a promising way to directly convert solar energy into chemical fuels to store solar energy for times of low or no sunlight [3]. Cuprous oxide Cu2O and cupric oxide CuO are highly auspicious materials for photocatalysis and photoelectrochemistry due to their small band gaps in the visible light region, the high abundance of copper in the earth crust – and thus low price – and low toxicity [4]. However, both Cu2O and CuO suffer from photocorrosion [5,6]. Although the deposition of buffer and protection layers of Cu2O in combination with a RuOx co-catalyst has been reported to result in stable water splitting photocathodes,[7] even the use of protection layers, such as titanium dioxide TiO2, has been shown not to be enough to prevent corrosion in some cases [8]. It may be possible to circumvent this problem by using ternary oxides instead of the binary copper oxides. Copper niobium oxides are especially interesting because niobium oxides are known for their high chemical stability, and several copper niobium oxides have been reported with band gaps in the visible light region with reported activities in photocatalysis or photoelectrochemistry [9,10]. Crystalline CuNbO3 has first been reported as cherry-red and monoclinic in 1977 by Wahlström and Marinder [11]. Diffraction analysis of single crystals confirmed the monoclinic structure (space group C2/m).[12] The band transition has been calculated to originate from Cu d-states forming the valence band (VB) to empty Nb d-states in the lower conduction band (CB) [9]. Moreover, indirect and direct transition are nearly identical in energy with a difference of approximately only 0.04 eV [9]. Amorphous films of CuNbO3 made by pulsed laser deposition were reported to be degenerated p-type semiconductors with a band gap of 2.6 eV [13]. Zoellner et al. reported the partial substitution of Nb with Ta, resulting in a small band gap increase, however, the band gap of CuNbO3 is reported as 1.89 eV indirect and 1.97 eV direct [14]. High-throughput screening of inkjet-printing was used to make photoactive CuNbO3-containing thin films [15]. A second modification of CuNbO3 exists, which is a high-pressure modification, and has also been reported as monoclinic with the possible space groups P2, Pm or P2/m [16]. Later works by Fukuda et al. however, specify the space group as Pc (no. 7) [17]. Another interesting copper niobium oxide is CuNb13O33, which was also reported as monoclinic and yellow in colour [11]. Cotton and Sandor determined C2/m as space group from single crystals, and described the sample as yellow needles [18]. They have further reported the existence of the two additional Cu(I) phases Cu11Nb23O63 and Cu17Nb19O56, which were obtained as a cherry-red mixture and were both reported as triclinic. The band gap of CuNb13O33 was also reported to be 2.25 eV [19]. CuNb3O8 has been reported as black, slightly paramagnetic, and also monoclinic with space group P2 1 /a [20]. The band transition has been calculated to occur between Cu d 10 in the VB and Nb d0 in the CB [10]. It is a p-type semiconductor with a better hole mobility than Cu2O [10]. The indirect band gap is reported as 1.26 eV, whereas a direct transition is slightly higher in energy with 1.47 eV. The solid solution LiNb3O8-CuNb3O8 has been reported; the band gap of LiNb3O8 is 3.89 eV and thus significantly larger than that for CuNb3O8 [21]. Heating CuNb3O8 in air results in partial oxidation and in the formation of Cu vacancies [22]. The H3ONb3O8/CuNb3O8 n/p heterojunction has been prepared via ion-exchange starting from KNb3O8 and has reported to result in higher photocatalytic hydrogen evolution rates than bare CuNb3O8 [23]. Metastable Cu2Nb8O21 was first synthesised in 2013 by Choi et al. from solvothermal ion exchange of Li3NbO4 nanoparticles in CuCl flux. The crystal structure is monoclinic (C2/m). This material is a p-type semiconductor with an indirect band gap of 1.43–1.65 eV, however, it decomposes already at room temperature within a few days [24]. For this reason, it has not been included in the photocatalysis study herein. CuNb2O6 has a monoclinic (P2 1 /c) and an orthorhombic phase (Pbcn) [25]. The monoclinic phase was reported to transform irreversibly into the orthorhombic phase at higher temperatures. Monoclinic CuNb2O6 has been reported to be a p-type semiconductor with a band gap of 3.5 eV.[26] However, later reports determined a band gap of 1.77 eV and a dark brown colour for monoclinic CuNb2O6 [27]. Band structure calculations actually showed the presence of two band gaps (2.07 eV and 0.92 eV) due to the formation of a partially occupied intermediate band near the Fermi level [27]. Both phases have been employed in sacrificial hydrogen evolution measurements in which the monoclinic phase was reported to be more active [28]. A third CuNb2O6 phase was synthesised by controlled decomposition starting from high-pressure synthesised CuNbO3, it is a cubic perovskite (I23) [29]. Triclinic Cu3Nb2O8 was first reported in 1977 [11]. It could be synthesised as single phase starting from freshly prepared CuO and CuNb2O6 [30]. The crystal structure was first solved in 2011 (space group P 1 ̅ ) [31]. It has been investigated for its multiferroic properties [31–35] and third-order non-linear optical properties [36]. Recently, Cu2Nb34O87 was reported and investigated as anode material for lithium ion batteries [37]. The material is monoclinic with Cu and Nb mixed on identical sites, space group A2/m. The metastable intermediates (Cu, Nb)12O99 and (Cu, Nb)15O37 could be isolated with a transport reaction;[38] but later attempts to synthesise them were unsuccessful [30]. To summarise, seven stable copper niobates exist that can be synthesised without high pressures, the vast majority of those have monoclinic crystal structures ( Table 1) and optical band gaps in the range of visible light. The coordination environments within these compounds depend on the oxidation state of Cu: Cu(I) compounds (CuNbO3, CuNb13O33 and CuNb3O8) consist of corner-sharing NbO6 octahedra with non-homogeneous Nb−O distances ( Fig. 1a-c). Cu is coordinated linearly by two O anions in CuNbO3 and CuNb13O33, but distorted tetrahedrally in CuNb3O8 with four shorter and two far longer Cu−O bonds. The two longer bonds are not opposed to each other; if the two longer Cu−O bonds would be included, the resulting polyhedron would be a heavily distorted octahedron. This difference compared to CuNbO3 and CuNb13O33 likely results from the mixed copper valence in CuNb3O8, which reportedly also encompasses small amounts of Cu(II) [20]. Cu(II) compounds in contrast have NbO6 octahedra – but also with non-homogeneous bond lengths –, which are edge-sharing (Cu3Nb2O8) or edge- and corner-sharing (CuNb2O6) (Fig. 1d-f). Cu(II) is coordinated planar-squared due to Jahn-Teller-distortions, however, Cu3Nb2O8 has a second Cu species which is coordinated square-pyramidal. Cu2Nb34O87 is a special case as Cu and Nb are located on mixed sites in centres of distorted, corner-sharing octahedra with a Cu amount of approximately 5% (Fig. 1g) [37]. Although some of the aforementioned materials were used in photocatalysis before, a systematic and comparing investigation concerning more than one single compound has been hitherto not performed. Herein, we investigated the syntheses of copper niobates – excluding metastable and high-pressure phases – via different pathways including solid-state, aqueous sol-gel and molten salt reaction with a high emphasis on phase purity. In some cases, we have managed to greatly simplify the syntheses of these compounds compared to previous literature reports, making the syntheses more economic as well. We have further investigated the chemical stability of these compounds and made a thorough analysis of optical and electronic properties. We employed these materials in photocatalytic hydrogen (H2) evolution to investigate their photochemical stability and the wavelength dependency of the photocatalytic activity. 2 Experimental part 2.1 Syntheses procedures All chemicals were used without further purification. Cuprous oxide Cu2O, copper(I) chloride CuCl, niobium(V) ethoxide and anhydrous ethanol were stored in a glove box with argon atmosphere to avoid oxidation and/or hydrolysis. CuNbO3 was synthesised via solid-state reaction at high temperatures in an inert gas flow. For synthesis of 1 g of CuNbO3, cuprous oxide Cu2O (99% Alfa Aesar, 200 mesh) and 650 mg niobium(V) oxide Nb2O5 (99.9% ChemPUR) were thoroughly grounded in an agate mortar, filled into a corundum combustion boat and put into a quartz glass tube within a tubular furnace. Cu2O had to be used in excess, ranging from 25 mol% (437 mg) to 100 mol% (700 mg). Annealing temperature and time were investigated, however, 900 °C and 24 h were found to result in a phase-pure material (see results below). The heating rate was set to 10 °C min−1; the furnace was allowed to cool naturally. A flow of inert gas – argon or nitrogen – was applied for 30 min before synthesis and for the entire time during synthesis including cool down. Afterwards the resulting powder was grounded and then washed with 5% ammonia solution in order to remove the Cu2O excess until the supernatant was colourless, washed with water several times and dried at 80 °C in air. Cu11Nb23O63 and Cu17Nb19O56 have been attempted to synthesise via solid-state reaction in inert gas. For Cu11Nb23O63, 409 mg Cu2O and 795 mg Nb2O5 were ground in an agate mortar, filled into a corundum combustion boat and placed into a quartz glass tube within a tubular furnace. For Cu17Nb19O56, 488 mg Cu2O and 675 mg Nb2O5 were used instead. The furnace was heated to 900 °C for 48 h with a heating rate of 10 °C min−1; the furnace was allowed to cool naturally. During the entire synthesis, including 30 min before heating and during cool-down the quartz glass tube was flushed with either argon or nitrogen. Afterwards, the samples were ground again, washed with 5% ammonia solution until the supernatant was colourless, then washed with water several times and dried at 80 °C. CuNb3O8 was synthesised by molten salt synthesis adapted from King et al. [22]. For synthesis of 1 g CuNb3O8, 228 mg Cu2O, 848 mg Nb2O5 and 263 mg copper(I) chloride CuCl (99% Alfa Aesar, 80 mesh) were thoroughly mixed in an agate mortar and filled into a corundum combustion boat. This boat was put into a tubular crucible (Haldenwanger, Morgan Advanced Materials) and this crucible – containing the combustion boat – was put open side first into another, slightly bigger tubular crucible. This setup was then placed into a desiccator connected to a gas vacuum manifold and evacuated and re-filled with argon three times. The crucibles were then entered into a quartz glass tube within a tubular furnace ( Fig. 2). The furnace was heated to 750 °C for 1 h, heating rate was set to 10 °C min−1 and the furnace was cooled naturally. An argon gas flow was applied during the synthesis and for several minutes before the crucibles were entered into the furnace in counter-flow direction. After the synthesis, the obtained product was ground into a powder, washed with 5% ammonia solution until the supernatant was colourless, then washed with water several times and dried at 80 °C in air. CuNb13O33 was also synthesised via solid-state reaction using 50 mg Cu2O and 960 mg (for 1 g of CuNb13O33) Nb2O5 that were thoroughly grounded in an agate mortar, filled into a corundum combustion boat, and put into a quartz glass tube within a tubular furnace. Time and temperature were investigated; however, already 10 h at 900 °C were sufficient. The heating rate was set to 10 °C min−1; the furnace was cooled naturally. Inert gas – argon or nitrogen – was flushed through the quartz glass tube during the entire synthesis and for 30 min before. After the synthesis, the resulting sample was ground again. Monoclinic CuNb2O6 was synthesised using an aqueous sol-gel reaction adapted from Schwertmann et al. [39] 3.65 g citric acid monohydrate (Bernd Kraft) and 3.38 g EDTA ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid (99.9% Alfa Aesar) were dissolved in 180 mL water using approximately 3 mL 25% ammonia solution (for 2 g CuNb2O6). The pH of the solution was then adjusted to 4–5 using concentrated nitric acid HNO3, followed by the stepwise addition of 20 mL 30% hydrogen peroxide H2O2 (Fisher Scientific), 1.399 g copper nitrate tri-hydrate Cu(NO3)2·3 H2O (99% Acros Organics) and 5.186 g ammonium niobium oxalate hydrate (99,99% Aldrich). The solution was subsequently heated to 95 °C until the volume has decreased to approximately 20 mL and was then transferred to a heating mantle (Winkler) and heated to 300 °C while stirring manually. Afterwards, the resulting black sample was ground to a powder and annealed in air at 800 °C for 10 h without cover, the heating rate was set to 5 °C min−1 and the furnace was allowed to cool naturally. For the synthesis of 2 g orthorhombic CuNb2O6 via solid-state reaction, 461 mg cupric oxide CuO (99.7% Alfa Aesar, 200 mesh) and 1.539 g Nb2O5 were ground thoroughly in an agate mortar, filled into a corundum crucible with cover, and annealed in air. Temperature and time were investigated; however, the optimum was found to be 1000 °C and 20 h. The heating rate was set to 10 °C min−1, the furnace was cooled naturally. Afterwards, the sample was ground again. Cu3Nb2O8 was also synthesised using aqueous sol-gel synthesis. For the synthesis of 1 g Cu3Nb2O8, 2.32 g EDTA and 2.50 g citric acid monohydrate were dissolved in 230 mL water using approximately 5 mL 25% ammonia solution. The solution was then acidified to a pH of 5 using approximately 3 mL concentrated nitric acid, followed by the addition of 10 mL 30% hydrogen peroxide and heating the solution to 60 °C. 1 mL niobium(V) ethoxide (99.9% abcr) was dissolved in approximately 10 mL anhydrous ethanol (Acros Organics) and added dropwise to the aqueous solution. After the solution was clear – and slightly yellowish – again, the heating was increased to 80 °C and 2.874 g Cu(NO3)2·3 H2O were dissolved in a few mL H2O and also added dropwise, resulting in a deep blue to green colour. The solution was further heated to 95 °C, resulting in temporary gas evolution and kept at 95 °C until the volume has decreased to approximately 20 mL, which have then been transferred to a heating mantle and heated to 300 °C while stirring manually. During this second heating step, the solution turns first black and becomes highly viscous, followed by a combustion reaction accompanied by smoke formation. After the thus obtained black sample has cooled down again, it was ground and annealed in air. Time and temperature have been varied, however, 950 °C at 10 h were found to result in a phase-pure material. The heating rate was set to 5 °C min−1; the furnace was cooled naturally. The powder was finely distributed on a rectangular incinerating dish and not closely packed into a crucible in order to guarantee a good contact with air to facilitate combustion of carbonaceous remains. Afterwards, the sample was ground again, shaken with approximately 30 mL of half-concentrated nitric acid for approximately 30 min and then centrifuged, whereupon the supernatant was discarded. The entire process was repeated until the supernatant remained colourless. The sample was subsequently washed neutral with water and then dried at 80 °C in air. The synthesis of Cu2Nb34O87 was attempted using solid-state reaction [37]. For the synthesis of 1 g Cu3Nb2O8, 34 mg CuO and 966 mg Nb2O5 were ground together in an agate mortar, filled into a corundum crucible with cover and annealed in air; the temperature and time were investigated. The heating ramp was set to 10 °C min−1; the furnace was cooled naturally. Afterwards, the obtained sample was ground again. 2.2 Chemical stability tests 200 mg sample were dispersed in 10 mL of a) H2O, b) 3% H2O2 (only for Cu(I) compounds), c) 2 M sodium hydroxide NaOH and) 2 M hydrochloric acid HCl and stirred at room temperature for one week. Afterwards, H2O2, NaOH and HCl samples were washed with water several times and all samples were dried at 80 °C in air. 2.3 Characterisation X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) was measured on a Malvern PANalytical Empyrean with non-monochromatised Cu Kα radiation. Theoretical diffraction patterns depicted for reference purposes in the XRD patterns shown in this work and crystal structures were calculated and drawn, respectively, with Diamond software from Crystal Impact, which was also used to calculate atomic distances. Rietveld refinements [40] were performed with the program Full Prof [41] using the Thompson-Cox-Hastings pseudo-Voigt function [42] with asymmetry correction [43] and Chebyshev polynomials as background. Instrumental resolution was determined using a LaB6 standard (NIST SRM 660c). Bond valence sum values were calculated with the parameters reported by Gagné and Hawthorne [44]. X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) were measured using a Physical Electronics PHI VersaProbe III Scanning XPS Microprobe employing monochromatised Al Kα radiation with a beam diameter of 100 µm. Survey spectra were recorded with a step size of 0.4 eV and a pass energy of 224 eV, whereas for high-resolution (HR) spectra a step size of 0.1 eV and a pass energy of 26 eV were used; the step time was 50 ms in both cases. An electron flood gun and slow-moving Ar ions were used to prevent sample charging. Samples were fixed on the sample holder using insulating, double-sided sticky tape. Samples were not sputter-cleaned before measurements in order to prevent sample changes due to preferential sputtering, with the exception of Cu foil (Plano) as reference. Data were analysed with CasaXPS using Shirley backgrounds and GL(30) line-shapes, except for Cu(0) and Cu(I) components within the Cu 2p 3/2 region for which (GL80) was used instead [45]. The C-C/C-H peak of the C 1 s signal was set to 284.8 eV for charge correction. Inelastic mean free paths (IMFP) were calculated with QUASES using the non-relativistic TPP2M formula [46]. Diffuse-reflection UV/vis/NIR absorption spectra were measured with a PerkinElmer Lambda 750 spectrometer using a Harrick praying mantis mirror unit and a spectralon pellet as white standard. The measured reflectance was converted into absorption with the Kubelka-Munk function; band gaps were further estimated using Tauc plots [47]. Raman spectra were measured with a Horiba Jobin Yvon LabRam system version 010 equipped with a 633 nm laser. Physisorption was measured with an Anton Paar QuantaTec ASIQ-MP-MP-AG using krypton at 77 K. Surface areas were determined with the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) method. Mercury porosimetry was measured with a Micromeritics Autopore III up to a maximum pressure of 210 MPa – tantamount to a pore size of 6 nm – and evaluated with Autopore software. Scanning electron microscopy images were measured with a Zeiss Leo 1530 and an acceleration voltage of 3 kV. Energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDXS) was measured with a Thermo Fisher Scientific Ultradry-EDX detector on the SEM mentioned above with an acceleration voltage of 20 kV. Samples were sputter-coated with platinum beforehand using a Cressington 208HR sputter-coater. For EDXS, several different spots were measured and averaged. Mott-Schottky analysis was performed with a Zahner Elektrik Zennium potentiostat at frequencies from 1 to 1000 Hz in 2 M KHCO3 solution (pH 9.5). The valid frequency range was measured beforehand using electrochemical impedance spectroscopy in a range from 105-1 Hz. A glass junction filled with 3 M NaCl solution was used to protect the Ag/AgCl reference electrode. Working electrodes were prepared by spin-coating using ethyl cellulose and α-Terpineol as binding agents [48]. For this, 200 mg sample were dispersed in 10 mL absolute ethanol and mixed with 40 mg ethyl-cellulose (48.0–49.5% (w/w) Sigma-Aldrich) and 1 g α-Terpineol (96% Alfa Aesar). The solution was then stirred overnight and heated gently to remove the EtOH to obtain a viscous solution. This solution was then deposited on 20 × 30 mm fluorine-doped tin oxide (FTO) coated glass-slides from XOP Glass using a SPS Polos spin coater operated at < 500 rpm for 10 s and then heated to 135 °C in air for complete drying. The electrodes were contacted using conductive copper tape and mounted into a Zahner Elektrik PECC-2 cell. 2.4 Photocatalytic experiments Sacrificial hydrogen evolution in simulated solar light was performed by using ultrasonication to disperse 50 mg sample in 135 mL purified H2O and 15 mL methanol MeOH (overall oxidation: CH3OH(l) + H2O(l) → CO2(g) + 3 H2(g), ΔG0 = 16.1 kJ/mol [49]) and filling this dispersion into a homemade glass reactor with a quartz glass window on top. As a co-catalyst, an aqueous solution of H2PtCl6 was added to result in a coverage of 0.1 wt% Pt. The reactor was purged with an argon 5.0 flow of 100 mL min−1, which was then reduced to 25 mL min−1 during the measurement using a Bronkhorst El-Flow Select mass flow controller. The temperature was kept constant at 20 °C with a Lauda ECO RE 1050 G thermostat. The evolved gases were detected with a Shimadzu GC2014 with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) using argon 5.0 as carrier and detector gas and a ShinCarbon ST column; one measurement lasts 10 min. The reactor was irradiated with a Quantum Design 300 W Xe lamp. During the course of the experiment, a 320 nm cut-off filter and a 420 nm cut-off filter were subsequently inserted into the beam path to partially remove or totally remove the amount of UV light within the beam, respectively. Sacrificial hydrogen evolution was also investigated in UV light. For this, 300 mg sample were dispersed in 550 mL purified water and 50 mL MeOH using ultrasonication. The dispersion was filled into an inner-immersion-type, homemade, double-walled glass reactor with a quartz glass inlet for the lamp. The reactor was purged with an argon 5.0 flow of 100 mL min−1 during the entire experiment. The temperature was kept constant at 10 °C with a Lauda RP845 thermostat. The evolved gases were detected with a Hiden Analytics HPR-20 Q/C quadrupole mass spectrometer. A Peschl Ultraviolet TQ718 mercury lamp was used for irradiation, lamp power was set to 500 W. After 2 h, the lamp was switched off and aqueous H2PtCl6 solution was added to result in a Pt coverage of 0.1 wt% using in-situ photodeposition. The lamp was turned on again after a few minutes and then finally turned off after 5 h. After both experiments, the samples were recovered using sedimentation and centrifugation to analyse their photochemical stability. Gas phase carbon dioxide CO2 reduction measurements were performed using a homemade stainless-steel reactor with a quartz glass window. 500 mg sample – previously decorated with 0.5 wt% Ag via stirring in AgNO3 solution followed by evaporation and subsequent annealing at 500 °C for 2 h in N2 flow – were placed into a glass dish, which has previously been annealed at 500 °C for 10 h in air to remove organic contaminants. Photolytic in-situ cleaning using He/H2O was used further to clean reactor and sample [50]. For CO2 reduction, 1 vol% CO2 in water vapour saturated He 5.0 were used, pressure was set to 1 bar (absolute), temperature was kept constant at 20 °C. A Quantum Design 300 W Xe lamp or a 365 nm Thorlabs LED with 1.29 W were used for illumination, respectively. Evolved gases were detected using a Shimadzu QP2020 NX GC-MS. 3 Results and discussion We have performed a very detailed synthesis study on the aforementioned materials, details are given in the SI. The most economic syntheses parameters for phase-pure copper niobium oxide materials are summarised in Table 2. For none of the materials, a synthesis time longer than 10 h is necessary anymore. Rietveld refinement of all six phase-pure compounds – CuNbO3, CuNb13O33, CuNb3O8, CuNb2O6 (orthorhombic and monoclinic) and Cu3Nb2O8 – further highlight the phase purity and high crystallinity of our materials ( Fig. 3). Although “goodness-of-fit” χ 2 and R-factors may appear (too) large at first glance, we want to emphasise that paradoxically the high quality of our patterns – sharp reflections and high counting intensities, the latter resulting in excellent signal-to-noise-ratios – may actually result in larger χ 2 or R wp values, even if the quality of obtained data is superior to refinements based on patterns of inferior qualities [51]. The crystal structure parameters obtained by Rietveld refinement ( Table 3) are highly similar to those previously reported (Table 1), which were in most cases measured with X-ray single crystal diffraction or neutron powder diffraction. This further highlights the high crystallinity of our samples and the high quality of the Rietveld refinements. The results from Rietveld refinement were used to calculate the metal−oxygen distances of the different copper niobates. The Nb−O distances within one NbO6 octahedra are inhomogeneous and range mostly between 1.8 − 2.3 Å ( Fig. 4a), resulting in – sometimes heavily – distorted octahedra. The observed spread of the Nb−O distances in copper niobates is far larger than the spread observed for NaNbO3 for which the distances are between 1.892 − 2.084 Å [52]. CuNb13O33 especially exhibits some rather short and long distances, respectively, which greatly surpass those observed for monoclinic Nb2O5 [53]. The wide spread and some unusual distances are likely an indication of the considerable distortion caused by the incorporation of Cu into the respective crystal structures. Whereas the Cu−O distances in CuNbO3 are highly similar to that observed for Cu2O, the distances calculated herein for CuNb13O33 are rather short and smaller than the 1.80 Å observed for CuNb13O33 single crystals (Fig. 4b) [18]. On the other hand the distances for CuNb3O8 – a Cu(I) compound – are far more similar to CuO than for Cu2O. Similar distances compared to those depicted have been previously reported, [20,22] indicating an intrinsic trait of CuNb3O8 instead of a refinement error. Instead it has been previously suggested that CuNb3O8 also contains a small part of Cu(II) randomly distributed on Cu(I) sites, [20] thus resulting in longer distances. The different distances also highlight the distorted tetrahedral coordination, which the two longer distances would change into a highly distorted octahedron. The distances of Cu(II) niobates closely resemble that of CuO, although monoclinic CuNb2O6 also shows one smaller distance. CuNb2O6 in general exhibits four small distances and two larger ones due to Jahn-Teller distortion, resulting in a square planar coordination environment. Cu3Nb2O8 has one Cu atom in square planar and one in square pyramidal coordination with an elongated distance between the second Cu and the apex of the pyramid. For CuNb3O8 and CuNb13O33 we have observed some slight amount of Cu vacancies, which would indicate some Cu oxidation. However, no Cu vacancies could be observed for CuNbO3. Bond valence sums were calculated for all metal cations (Fig. 4c). The values for Nb are often well below the expected value of 5 especially for the Cu(I) niobates, which were synthesised in inert gas. Bond valence sums for Nb below 5 were also previously reported for CuNb3O8 [21]. This could maybe be an indication for the presence of Nb(IV) defects. On the other hand, bond valence sums for Cu match well with the expected value, except for CuNb13O33, which is a result of the small Cu−O distances. 3.1 Morphological characterisation The morphology of the obtained samples depends heavily on the compound and synthesis strategy to obtain phase pure compounds ( Fig. 5 and Fig. S8, SI). Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images show that the morphology of CuNbO3 is sponge-like: primary particles with smooth surfaces are densely intergrown with each other, forming a continuous three-dimensional network with voids in between. Overall particle sizes can be up to several tens of µm. CuNb3O8 in contrast, consists of platelets with almost serrated surfaces which are 10–30 µm large and approximately one µm thick. CuNb13O33 consists of rod-like particles that are assembled into large, sponge-like aggregates; however, the porosity surpasses that of CuNbO3 by far. The sol-gel synthesis and the comparatively low annealing temperature of monoclinic CuNb2O6 result in small primary particles, which are commonly below 100 nm in diameter. These particles are agglomerated into larger structures that exhibit large slits and other voids. Their likely origin is the formation of gases during combustion and/or annealing [56]. In contrast, orthorhombic CuNb2O6 – formed by solid-state reaction – consists of irregularly formed particles in µm range. While Cu3Nb2O8 also consists of µm-sized, irregularly formed particles, these particles further show µm-sized pores, which are far more spherical than those observed for monoclinic CuNb2O6. The synthesis of phase-pure Cu3Nb2O8 requires the use of a Cu excess, which forms CuO upon annealing (see syntheses part above). This CuO excess is then dissolved and washed away with nitric acid, most probably resulting in the formation of these pores. Samples that have been shown to be macroporous by SEM images were further analysed with mercury intrusion porosimetry ( Fig. 6). CuNb13O33 shows the highest pore volume and a broad pore size distribution between 2 µm to approximately 100 µm. The pore volume of CuNbO3 in contrast, is less than half of that of CuNb13O33; the maximum of the pore size distribution is around 6.5 µm. The pore volume of Cu3Nb2O8 lies in between, however, the pore size distribution has a rather sharp maximum at about 2 µm. Additionally, there are some larger pores with diameters between 10 and 150 µm. Due to the high temperatures necessary for syntheses of phase-pure copper niobates, the resulting surface areas are rather small (Fig. S9, SI). The surface area of most compounds lies between 0.2 and 0.5 m2 g−1 with two exceptions: one is CuNb13O33 with a comparatively high surface area of 1 m2 g−1 due the high porosity of the particle aggregates, which has also been shown by SEM and mercury intrusion porosimetry. The other exception is monoclinic CuNb2O6 with a surface area of 3.6 m2 g−1 due to its small particle sizes. 3.2 Spectroscopic characterisation All copper niobates absorb visible light and are intensely colourful (Fig. S10, SI): CuNbO3 is cherry-red, CuNb3O8 is black, CuNb13O33 is saturated yellow, monoclinic CuNb2O6 is a pale yellowish, whereas orthorhombic CuNb2O6 is dark grey and Cu3Nb2O8 is reddish-brown. The colours of the Cu(I) niobates match with those reported in the literature, [9,10,18,19] however, those of Cu(II) niobates are markedly different. Monoclinic CuNb2O6 has been reported as greenish-grey or dark brown or black, whereas the orthorhombic form has been reported yellowish or yellowish-green, which is a considerable difference to the materials obtained herein [11,27,28]. Furthermore, Cu3Nb2O8 has been described as amber [11]. The visible light absorption of these materials has been more closely investigated with UV/vis/NIR absorption spectroscopy ( Fig. 7a). The absorption spectra of Cu(I) and Cu(II) compounds are distinctly different due to the presence of d−d absorption bands for Cu(II) compounds. Due to the asymmetric coordination environments of Cu2+ as a result of Jahn-Teller distortion, these absorption bands are visible, although they would actually be forbidden in some cases [28]. Orthorhombic CuNb2O6 and Cu3Nb2O8 show highly intense d−d absorption bands with two distinctive peaks centred on 800 nm and 1000 nm; their intensity is equal to that of the fundamental absorption edge. Monoclinic CuNb2O6 in contrast, shows far weaker absorption bands centred on 900 nm and 1400 nm. Interestingly, the relative intensities of the absorption edge and the d−d absorption bands are significantly different to those reported in the literature [28]. The intensity of the d−d bands depend on the strength of the Jahn-Teller distortion, which depend on the atomic distances and angles, which in turn will depend somehow on the synthesis conditions of the respective compound. This is also the likely reason why the reported colours of the Cu(II) compounds are so different, since the resulting colour is a mixture of the respective absorption of the fundamental edge and the d−d bands. The determined band gaps are in the range of 2.0–2.7 eV with the exception of CuNb3O8, whose absorption edge is located in the NIR region with a resulting band gap of 1.26 eV. Optical band gaps can be determined more accurately with Tauc plots, however, the nature of the semiconductor – direct or indirect – has to be known. CuNbO3 and CuNb3O8 are known to be indirect semiconductors, however, the relative flatness of the bands result in low charge carrier mobilities and high effective masses [9,10]. Consequently, there is also a direct transition only slightly higher in energy than the lowest, indirect one. The indirect band gaps of CuNbO3 and CuNb3O8 are 2.00 eV and 1.12 eV (Fig. S11a, SI), respectively, which is in good accordance to the literature [9,10]. The determined direct band gaps would be 2.10 eV and 1.36 eV, respectively, however, CuNb3O8 would have an additional transition at 2.08 eV (Fig. S11b, SI). For CuNb13O33 no information about the optical properties or kind of semiconductor transition are known. The band gap determined via Kubelka-Munk absorption is 2.33 eV, whereas Tauc plots would result in 2.25 eV and 2.58 eV for indirect and direct transitions, respectively. Due to the better fits with the value determined via Kubelka-Munk we would presume that CuNb13O33 is more likely an indirect semiconductor. Monoclinic CuNb2O6 has been calculated as an indirect semiconductor too, however the bands have also been characterised as flat – especially the valence band –, resulting in low conductivities [27]. The indirect band gap is 2.55 eV determined via Tauc plot, and a slightly higher value of 2.69 eV results from the Kubelka-Munk absorption spectrum. This is in good agreement with the value of 2.7 eV reported before,[28,58] however, the band gap has also been reported as 1.7 eV and 3.5 eV [26,27]. The band gap of orthorhombic CuNb2O6 is 2.37 eV determined via Kubelka-Munk and 2.07 eV and 2.58 eV by indirect and direct Tauc plots, respectively. All values are slightly smaller than the 2.7 eV reported in the literature [28]. Cu3Nb2O8 has a band gap of 2.11 eV via Kubelka-Munk analysis, whereas Tauc plots result in an indirect band gap of 1.94 eV and a direct one of 2.25 eV. All these values are considerably smaller than the 2.5 eV and 2.8 eV reported in the literature before [36,57]. The determination of accurate band gaps for Cu(II) compounds is impeded by the strong d−d absorption band, resulting in no discernible baseline for intersection with the absorption edge (Fig. S11, SI). Information about further structural distortions can be obtained by Raman spectroscopy. Raman spectra of CuNbO3, CuNb13O33 and orthorhombic CuNb2O6 have so far not been reported before; moreover, we were unable to obtain a Raman spectrum of CuNb3O8 with our system. Nevertheless, the number of theoretically allowed Raman modes according to selection rules for CuNb3O8 should be 72 [59]. However, the number of observable Raman modes is usually well below the number of theoretically allowed Raman modes (Table S1, SI). The Raman spectra of monoclinic CuNb2O6 and Cu3Nb2O8 are significantly different from those reported before, which furthermore also differ from each other [27,36]. All copper niobates exhibit several Raman bands – in some cases strongly overlapping – in the range of 100–500 cm−1, which can be assigned to O−Nb−O bending vibrations within the NbO6 octahedra [60]. Monoclinic Nb2O5 shows strong Raman bands from 550 to 800 cm−1 belonging to Nb−O−Nb bridging bonds, resulting in the anisotropy of the NbO6 octahedra [60]. Strong Raman bonds in this region have also been observed for slightly distorted, ternary niobium oxides [61]. In contrast, most copper niobates presented herein show two strong Raman bands between 800 and 1050 cm−1 (Fig. 7b). The exception is CuNb13O33 that shows only two small bands at 980–1010 cm−1, but more and stronger bands between 550 and 700 cm−1. However, CuNb13O33 has not only by far the smallest copper amount but also a high structural similarity with monoclinic Nb2O5. These intense Raman bands between 800 and 1000 cm−1 have been observed before for highly distorted niobium oxides: shorter Nb−O bond distances – tantamount with a higher bond order – result in a shift towards higher wavenumbers [61]. CuNb13O33 shows these Raman bands at the highest wavenumbers of all copper niobates, but CuNb13O33 has also the smallest Nb−O distances as shown above (Fig. 4a). The shift of the Raman bands further supports the high structural distortions of copper niobates shown above via Rietveld refinements. Moreover, all copper niobates show two Raman bands at these high wavenumbers, but the relative intensities are changing for the different materials. This doublet likely results from the symmetric and antisymmetric stretching modes of Nb−O bonds [61]. Raman bands at these wavenumbers have been further ascribed to Nb−O−Nb bonds of edge-sharing NbO6 octahedra within Nb oxides – that do not include a second metal cation [60,62]. However, the Cu(I) oxides herein consist of corner-sharing octahedra, whereas Cu(II) oxides consists of edge- and corner-sharing octahedra (Fig. 1) and no second doublet can be observed for CuNb2O6 to account for the different octahedra. Instead, this ascription further supports our theory of shorter-than-normal bond distances, since the metal−metal distance within two edge-sharing MO6 octahedra is shorter than for two corner-sharing octahedra. Band positions were estimated with Mott-Schottky analysis with working electrodes prepared via spin coating. The resulting slope is negative in all cases, clearly indicating p-type semiconducting behaviour for all materials (Fig. 7c and Fig. S12, SI). Monoclinic CuNb2O6 was not measured this way due to its instability in aqueous dispersion (see further below) as Mott-Schottky analysis is only valid for single-phase materials. The estimated flat band potentials are centred at 1.9 V (vs. RHE, pH = 0), with the exception of CuNb3O8 whose flat band potential is slightly higher with 2.1 V. A slight frequency dependence has been observed (Fig. S12, SI), those frequency dispersions can have a plethora of reasons [63]. One of those reasons can be a frequency-dependent relative permittivity or dielectric constant. Such frequency dependency has been observed for orthorhombic CuTa2O6 – not isostructural with orthorhombic CuNb2O6 – for which the relative permittivity changes several orders of magnitude over a wide frequency range [64]. The charge carrier density can be obtained from the slope of the linear approximation, however, for this calculation the relative permittivity of the semiconductor must be known. Unfortunately, these values are mostly unknown for the copper niobates discussed herein. Although a high relative permittivity with extensive frequency dependence has been reported for CuNb2O6, it is the perovskite-type, cubic polymorph, which requires high-pressures for synthesis, [29] for this reason, it is not included herein. For Cu3Nb2O8, the relative permittivity has only been reported for a small temperature range, i.e. 22–28 K, [34] which is far from our measurements at room temperature. The obtained flat band potentials can be further used to determine the valence band position and – in combination with band gaps – the conduction band positions (Fig. 7d). The herein experimentally obtained values are located at far more positive potentials than those reported previously in the literature. The obtained valence band positions are also similar for all copper niobates investigated herein, which is also in contradiction to the literature. Except for CuNb3O8, the thus estimated conduction band minima are located at only slightly more negative potentials than the hydrogen evolution potential. Considering the uncertainties of Mott-Schottky analysis – especially for powder derived electrodes – and band gap estimation via UV/vis/NIR absorption spectroscopy, it remains doubtful if these materials are truly suitable for photocatalytic hydrogen evolution. The position also makes it unlikely that the valence band maximum consists of O 2p states – which is oftentimes the case for transition metal oxides with unoccupied d states – as these states would be located at a potential of approximately 3 V.[65] The band gap excitation has been calculated to occur between occupied Cu 3d states in the valence band and unoccupied Nb 4d states in the conduction band, at least for CuNbO3 and CuNb3O8.[9,22] Considering the overall similar band positions, the same is likely true for the other copper niobates as well. Surface analysis performed by XPS showed the absence of surface impurities, except for a minor Na 1 s signal observed for monoclinic CuNb2O6 (Fig. S13a, SI). The inelastic mean free paths have been calculated to be between 17.4 and 18.7 Å (for an electron energy of 900 eV),[46] resulting in an information depth of around 5 nm. Quantifications show some derivations from the expected stoichiometry as most compounds show a slight Cu deficiency (Fig. S13b, SI), with the exception of CuNb13O33, which in contrast shows a considerable Cu excess, likely resulting from the slight excess employed in the synthesis. This Cu deficiency could result from the p-type nature of copper niobates (see above), but may be exacerbated by the post-syntheses washing processes necessary for most compounds. EDXS measurements on the other hand show small Cu excesses, however, EDXS suffer from an overlap of X-ray energies of Nb and Pt – used as coating for SEM measurements –, which could explain the derivation in EDXS. High-resolution Cu 2p 3/2 spectra show a mixture of oxidation states for all copper niobates ( Fig. 8a), the distribution between Cu(I) and Cu(II) species depends mainly on the nominal oxidation state of the respective copper compound. For CuNbO3 and CuNb13O33 – both Cu(I) compounds – the main peak is located at 932.5 eV and 932.6 eV, respectively, and can be ascribed to oxidic Cu(I). For comparison, we have measured Cu, Cu2O and CuO as reference compounds (Fig. S13c, SI). The binding energy of Cu(I) in Cu2O is 932.3 eV, which is also in good accordance with literature.[45] Furthermore, Cu2O also shows extensive amounts of Cu(II) as well, indicating a general tendency of Cu(I) compounds for surface oxidation. The peaks at about 933.7 eV belongs to an oxidic Cu(II) species,[45] as well as a second, smaller one at about 935.3 eV which results from the multiplet splitting of Cu(II) with d 9 electron configuration. This peak is considerably shifted with respect to CuO (934.5 eV), likely resulting from the different chemical environment. The entire Cu 2p 3/2 spectrum of CuNb3O8 – also a Cu(I) compound – seems to be shifted towards lower binding energies, however, since this shift is limited to Cu and does not extend to Nb 3d or O 1 s it cannot be the reason of charging or an erroneous charge correction. Moreover, the same shift can be observed for CuNb3O8 after photocatalysis (see further below), so it seems to be an intrinsic trait of CuNb3O8. The two main peaks are located at 931.1 eV and 932.6 eV, while the latter would normally be attributed to Cu(I), we still presume it to be actually Cu(II) in nature due to the observed multiplet peak at 934.7 eV and to account for the expected surface oxidation. The 931.1 Cu(I) peak is located at an unusually low energy for copper. Using a fit with an additional component would not result in different binding energies (not shown). The entire shift of CuNb3O8 likely results from an electron-rich environment, which seems counterintuitive considering its p-type nature. These results complement the results obtained by Rietveld refinement described above, which showed some bulk Cu oxidation for CuNb3O8 and CuNb13O33. The Cu(II) compounds on the other hand also show three peaks: the main oxidic Cu(II) peak at 934.1 ± 0.1 eV (mean value and standard deviation, respectively), the smaller Cu(II) peak at 935.0 ± 0.0 eV and a Cu(I) peak at 932.4 ± 0.1 eV with little to no derivation between the different compounds. The prevalence of Cu(I) defects within ternary Cu(II) compounds has been observed before in CuTa2O6 [66,67] and is a consequence of the high temperature annealing. The only difference in the Cu 2p 3/2 spectrum of the three Cu(II) compounds is a further Cu(I) peak in monoclinic CuNb2O6 located at 930.8 eV. The binding energy is similar to the one observed before for CuNb3O8 (see above) and indicates the presence of a second Cu(I) defect species, this one located in a more electron-rich environment as the first. All compounds further show the presence of shake-up satellite features between 940 and 945 eV, which are commonly observed for Cu(II) oxides [68]. To further identify the different Cu species, Cu L3M45M45 spectra were fitted using peak profiles proposed by Biesinger (Fig. 8b and Fig. S13d, SI)):[45] for Cu(I) niobates, the constraints were relaxed for Cu(I) components in order to accommodate the different chemical environment compared to Cu2O, whereas the constraints for Cu(II) components were maintained. For Cu(II) niobates, the procedure was reversed. CuNbO3 and CuNb13O33 have peak maxima at kinetic energies of 915.5 ± 0.2 eV, which is lower compared to 917.1 eV for Cu2O and the Cu(I) peaks observed at 916.7 ± 0.1 for other copper niobates. On the other hand, the maximum for CuNb3O8 is located at 916.5 eV, which is slightly lower than for Cu2O [45]. On the other hand, the Cu(II) peak all have highly similar kinetic energies centred on 917.8 ± 0.2 eV, which is identical to the value observed for CuO. The difference between the Cu states within the different copper niobates can be further highlighted via the (modified) Auger parameter, i.e. the sum of the Cu 2p3/2 binding energy and the Cu L3M45M45 kinetic energy, and a Wagner-plot (Fig. 8c). This value was calculated for both the Cu(I) and Cu(II) species within each compound. The Cu(II) species are located closely together with Auger parameters between 1851 and 1852 eV. The exception is CuNb3O8, whose parameter is slightly lower at 1850.5 eV, however, its Cu(II) nature becomes more obvious, despite the low binding energy. The Auger parameter of the Cu(I) species depends on the formal oxidation state: for the Cu(II) compounds (CuNb2O6 and Cu3Nb2O8) it is about 1849.25 ± 0.2 eV and similar to the 1849.4 eV observed for Cu2O. For Cu(I) niobates, the value is 1847.9 ± 0.2 eV, similar to those observed for Cu(I) halides [45]. Interestingly, the Auger parameter calculated with the low binding energy defect state of monoclinic CuNb2O6 has a similar value, thus further supporting the Cu(I) nature of these defects. The ratio of Cu(I) to Cu(II) is highly different for the Cu(I) niobates (Fig. S13e, SI), CuNbO3 has by far the highest amount of Cu(II) and CuNb13O33 the lowest, whereas the amount of Cu(I) is similar for all Cu(II) niobates. The Nb 3d spin-orbit doublets were fitted using an area ratio of 2:3, a doublet separation energy of 2.72 eV [69] and identical FWHMs within each doublet, but different for each doublet (Fig. 8d). Two sets of doublets were necessary to obtain a good fit, however, for CuNb3O8 a third pair had to be added. The Nb 3d 5/2 binding energy of one doublet is virtually identical for all copper niobates with 206.7 ± 0.1 eV and can be ascribed to Nb(V) within mixed Nb(V) oxides, whose binding energy is slightly lower compared to the binary oxide Nb2O5 [69,70]. The Nb 3d 5/2 binding energy of the other, smaller doublet is 207.6 ± 0.1 eV for Cu(I) compounds and 207.2 ± 0.1 eV for Cu(II) compounds. Since the energy is so clearly connected with Cu, it is worth reasoning that this additional Nb 3d doublet results from the high abundance of Cu defects, i.e. Nb atoms in the vicinity of Cu defects. For CuNb3O8, the third doublet at 206.2 eV is similar to the binding energy reported for niobium(IV) oxide NbO2, [71,72] consequently we would ascribe this signal to Nb(IV) defects within CuNb3O8. The main peak of the O 1 s spectra is located at 530.0 ± 0.0 eV and can be ascribed to lattice oxide (Fig. 8e). A second, smaller peak at 530.8 ± 0.1 eV can be assigned to defective oxygen, i.e. oxygen in the vicinity of defects, which is commonly observed for transition metal oxides [68,73]. A third peak at approximately 532 eV belongs to adsorbed water and/or to carbonaceous oxygen species [73]. The ratio of defective to lattice oxygen is different for each compound (Fig. S13e, SI), CuNbO3 and Cu3Nb2O8 possess the highest amounts of defects. The C 1 s spectra consists mainly of the C-C/C-H peak (set to 284.8 eV for charge correction), with two smaller peaks for C-O and OC-O at higher binding energies (Fig. S13f, SI). Due to the high annealing temperatures, the likely origin is adventitious carbon. 3.3 Investigation of chemical stability In order to find out the chemical stability of copper niobates, all compounds were stirred in H2O, 2 M HCl, 2 M NaOH and – for Cu(I) niobates only – in 3% H2O2 for 7 days at room temperature. After such treatment in H2O and H2O2, CuNbO3 showed no changes, indicating stability in water and against chemical oxidation, however, stirring in HCl or NaOH resulted in its partial decomposition ( Fig. 9a). On the other hand, even stirring in water results in the decomposition of monoclinic CuNb2O6 (Fig. 9b): a slow phase transformation of the monoclinic into the orthorhombic polymorph is visible (Fig. S14a, SI). However, no such transformation is visible for the powder even after a longer time of storage under ambient conditions, indicating that this transformation process occurs only for an aqueous dispersion. Although monoclinic CuNb2O6 has been applied in aqueous dispersion before,[28] no such transformation process was hitherto reported. None of the other copper niobates show any signs of decomposition after aqueous treatments (Fig. S14b-e, SI). 3.4 Photocatalysis The photocatalytic activity of copper niobates was investigates using sacrificial hydrogen H2 evolution; monoclinic CuNb2O6 was not measured due to its instability in aqueous dispersion (see above). The light dependency of this reaction was further investigated by using two different light sources: one is a xenon lamp, which even without an AM 1.5 G filter emits mostly visible light; the other is a mercury lamp emitting mainly UV light. The detected amounts of hydrogen upon illumination with a 300 W Xe lamp are miniscule ( Fig. 10a). Methanol was used as a sacrificial agent and hexachloroplatinate(IV) H2PtCl6 solution was added in the beginning for in-situ photodeposition of Pt nanoparticles as co-catalyst. During the course of the measurement, a 420 nm filter was inserted into the beam path to remove the UV light from the lamp spectrum (see arrows in Fig. 10a). As a consequence, the H2 evolution rate decreased to zero for all samples, therefore it seems that the observed H2 evolution does not result from the band gap excitation by visible light but rather from higher energy excitations with UV light. The inactivity in simulated solar light could have several reasons: one is the estimation of the conduction band positions for most of the copper niobates only slightly above the proton reduction potential (Fig. 7d), thus resulting in only small overpotentials to facilitate the reaction. A second reason could be the low mobility of photogenerated charge carriers: the calculated band structures for at least three copper niobates – CuNbO3, CuNb3O8 and CuNb2O6 – are rather shallow at the band edges [9,10,27]. This results in high effective masses and thus low mobilities of photogenerated charge carriers, which are inversely proportional to the curvatures of the respective bands [9]. Consequently, photogenerated charge carriers are unable to spatially separate thus resulting in high recombination rates and low photocatalytic activities. The combination of small driving force and sluggish charge carrier dynamics is a serious hindrance for hydrogen evolution and photocatalysis in general. Since the materials are very active in UV light irradiation, the latter seems to be the most important reason. A further drawback are the small surface areas due to large particle sizes resulting from the high annealing temperatures necessary to obtain phase-pure materials. Reports from other research groups in the literature also confirm the poor activity of copper niobates in visible light photocatalysis, although a direct comparison of numbers is problematic due to different reaction conditions such as lamp intensity, amounts of sample and co-catalyst, reactor geometry, etc. Using a rough calculation to account for these differences results in actually nearly similar rates for CuNbO3 [14] and CuNb3O8 [21,23]. For CuNb2O6, the activity reported in the literature is in the single nmol h−1 range and far below to what is observed herein; interestingly, the monoclinic polymorph is reported to be more active than the orthorhombic one [28]. We would conjecture that the resulting phase transformation towards orthorhombic due to the instability of the monoclinic polymorph is the reason for that, as the formation of a heterojunction can greatly increase the photocatalytic activity [74]. Due to the low activity in simulated solar light, photocatalysis was also measured in UV light (Fig. 10b). At the start the samples were measured without Pt co-catalyst. After approximately 150 min (different times for CuNb13O33), the lamp was switched off – resulting in a declining H2 evolution rate – and aqueous H2PtCl6 solution was added through a self-sealing rubber-gasket. After a few minutes in order to achieve a homogeneous dispersal of the Pt precursor within the reaction volume, the lamp was switched on again, resulting in the in-situ photodeposition of 0.1 wt.-% Pt. After about 350 min, the lamp was finally switched off and H2 evolution rates declined to zero, thus showing that the H2 evolution was truly photocatalytic in nature. Methanol was used as a sacrificial agent. All samples are able to evolve H2 even without a co-catalyst, the magnitude of the evolution rates greatly surpassing those observed for Xe light (Fig. 10a). The photocatalytic activity without co-catalyst is highly similar for the Cu(I) niobates (CuNbO3, CuNb3O8 and CuNb13O33), indicating that the activity is not limited by the different crystal structures, band gaps or surface areas but instead by a more intrinsic communality. The band excitation responsible for the photogeneration of charge carriers in UV light is obviously not the optical band gap excitation, but instead one with higher energy. The band gap transition causing the visible light absorption occurs between occupied Cu 3d and unoccupied Nb 4d states [9,10]. Removal of Cu from the structures would result in drastically increased band gaps: The calculated band gap of e.g. orthorhombic ZnNb2O6 is 3.55 eV, thus 1.5 eV larger than that of CuNb2O6 [27]. The band gap of Nb2O5 depends on the polymorph and is about 3.7 eV for amorphous, tetragonal and orthorhombic Nb2O5, while the band gap of the monoclinic polymorph is slightly higher with 4.2 eV; the transition occurs between O 2p and Nb 4d [75]. It is likely this transition that is responsible for the higher band gap in ZnNb2O6. Furthermore, it is also likely this O 2p and Nb 4d transition is the photocatalytically active one in UV light here, instead of the Cu 3d to Nb 4d transition. As mentioned above, the calculated band structures for at least three copper niobates – CuNbO3, CuNb3O8 and CuNb2O6 – are rather shallow at the band edges, but with UV irradiation, this transition becomes an underlying excitation. Moreover, in UV light, the major absorption changes from a d-d transition (Cu 3d to Nb 4d) to a p-d transition (O 2p to Nb 4d), which can, due to orbital symmetry reasons, also influence the lifetimes of excited states. On the other hand, the activity of the Cu(II) niobates (CuNb2O6 and Cu3Nb2O8) is markedly different: whereas triclinic Cu3Nb2O8 shows the lowest activity of all compounds, orthorhombic CuNb2O6 shows the highest. As Cu3Nb2O8 has actually the higher surface area – and is macroporous in addition – neither surface area nor better mass transport properties can be the reason. As the photocatalytic activity stems from UV light, the slight difference in band gaps also cannot be the reason. Furthermore, the estimated band positions are also highly similar. On the other hand, Cu3Nb2O8 has a nearly doubled amount of defective oxygen compared to orthorhombic CuNb2O6 as shown by XPS (Fig. S13e, SI). However, different amounts of defective oxygen do not seem to influence the photocatalytic activity of Cu(I) niobates. Instead the likely reason for the different activities could be the symmetry of the respective crystal system: for NaNbO3 it has been shown that the cubic polymorph has an intrinsically higher activity than the one of lesser symmetry [52]. The reason for that is that the higher symmetry results in higher electron mobilities and better charge carrier transport properties as electron diffusion is possible in three directions for cubic NaNbO3 but becomes restricted in only one direction as symmetry decreases. The photodeposition results in only small to none increases of the H2 evolution rate (Fig. 10b). The reason could be the necessary overpotential of Pt for H2 evolution with respect to the conduction band of the copper niobates (Fig. 7d). Although Pt has one of the lowest overpotentials for H2 evolution, it is still between − 0.27 V and − 0.09 V [76]. As such, the driving force of electrons in the conduction band to travel to Pt nanoparticles on the copper niobate surface is rather minimal if it exists at all. Since CuNb13O33 has the highest conduction band minimum, it also has the highest driving force of electrons to move onwards to Pt, and it also shows the highest H2 evolution rate increase (> 30%) upon Pt photodeposition. All materials were further tested in non-sacrificial, gas-phase CO2 reduction under high-purity conditions; however, no reaction products could be detected. Considering the above results for sacrificial hydrogen evolution, the likely reason for this is that neither the used Xe lamp nor the UV LED emits enough UV light of suitable wavelengths. Furthermore, the absence of sacrificial agents hinders the photocatalytic activity significantly. As Cu2O and CuO are well-known to be susceptible for photocorrosion,[5,6] all samples were recovered after photocatalysis and analysed. The CuNbO3 sample irradiated in UV light shows small reflections of CuNb13O33 (Fig. S15a, SI), indicating an UV irradiation-induced phase transformation. This decomposition can be further seen in the changed UV/vis/NIR absorption spectra (Fig. S16a, SI). However, no such transformation is visible for the sample irradiated under Xe lamp light. On the other hand, for CuNb3O8 and CuNb13O33 neither the XRD patterns nor the absorption spectra show any signs of changes after irradiation (Figs. S15 and S16 b and c respectively, SI). Orthorhombic CuNb2O6 shows several changes after photocatalysis, however, the changes depend on the light source. After irradiation with Xe lamp light, all reflections have shifted to smaller angles tantamount to larger unit cell constants, moreover, reflection intensities have shifted, especially for (h00) and (002) reflections (Fig. S15d and e, SI). For the UV irradiated sample these differences are not visible, instead the (311) reflection is slightly broadened at its base, which could indicate symmetry breaking tantamount with a phase transformation to the monoclinic phase. Although these changes in the XRD pattern are rather miniscule, the process becomes more evident in the absorption spectra (Fig. S16d, SI). The absorption edge has shifted to smaller wavelengths after UV irradiation and the intensity of the d−d band absorption has decreased. By comparison with monoclinic CuNb2O6, it becomes evident that the spectrum of UV irradiated, orthorhombic CuNb2O6 becomes more similar to that of monoclinic CuNb2O6, indicating a partial phase transformation. In hindsight, this also explains why orthorhombic CuNb2O6 showed the highest H2 evolution rate under UV irradiation: the transformation from one polymorph into another creates a heterojunction, which can drastically increase the photocatalytic activity by spatially separating the photogenerated charge carriers.[74,77] The XRD patterns of Cu3Nb2O8 after photocatalysis show small reflections of CuO, furthermore the absorption spectrum also shows slight changes after photocatalysis (Figs. S15f and S16e, SI). The samples irradiated under UV light were further investigated by XPS and EDXS, since the higher light intensity of immersion lamps should result in more drastic changes compared to those samples irradiated with a Xe lamp. Quantification by XPS shows some changes in the surface composition (Fig. S17a, SI), whereas CuNb13O33 and CuNb2O6 show a copper depletion on the surface compared to before, CuNbO3 and Cu3Nb2O8 actually have an increased copper amount on the surface. Moreover, EDXS shows a slight Cu depletion of most samples, indicating the leeching of copper from the bulk volume. Furthermore, survey XP spectra show a slight amount of fluorine for some samples afterwards, most likely resulting from abrasion of the PTFE coated stirring bar (Fig. S17b, SI). High-resolution Cu 2p 3/2 spectra show the same peaks as before ( Fig. 11a), however, their respective intensities and thus the ratio of Cu(I) to Cu(II) states have changed significantly for some samples (Fig. 11b, black). Whereas the Cu(I) content has only increased marginally for Cu(I) niobates, it has increased tremendously for Cu(II) niobates, especially for Cu3Nb2O8. Therefore it appears that Cu(II) niobates suffer from reductive photocorrosion during photocatalysis, which has been observed before for CuO and CuNb2O6 photocathodes [6,58]. Cu L3M45M45 spectra also show increased Cu(I) components after photocatalysis (Fig. S17c, SI). Nb 3d spectra remain mostly unchanged (Fig. S17d, SI); however, the amount of Nb(V) linked to Cu defects has increased for all samples that have shown photocorrosion (Fig. 11b, red). Furthermore, the Nb(IV) defects in CuNb3O8 remain unchanged, indicating that these defect states are stable in water and under UV irradiation. While the O 1 s spectra consist of the same peaks as before (Fig. S17e, SI), the ratio of defective to lattice oxygen has also changed (Fig. 11b, turquoise). The amount of defective oxygen has increased significantly for the samples showing photocorrosion – CuNbO3, CuNb2O6 and Cu3Nb2O8. On the other hand, C 1 s spectra show a large C-C/C-H peak and smaller peaks for COx species typical for adventitious carbon (Fig. S17f, SI). To summarise, CuNbO3 decomposes under UV irradiation, whereas CuNb2O6 and Cu3Nb2O8 show reductive photocorrosion. CuNb2O6 further shows a photo-induced phase transformation towards its monoclinic polymorph. CuNb3O8 and CuNb13O33 seem to be stable under the employed conditions. 4 Conclusion We have systematically investigated and optimised the syntheses of copper niobates in order to obtain highly crystalline and phase-pure materials. We managed to develop syntheses procedures that are far more convenient, less dangerous, and more economic than previously used ones. These materials are chemically highly stable with the exception of monoclinic CuNb2O6 that undergoes a phase transformation in aqueous dispersion towards the orthorhombic polymorph. Copper niobates have furthermore a rich defect-chemistry, resulting in mixed copper oxidation states, which further result in the creation of Nb defects. These copper niobates are p-type semiconductors with band gaps suitable for visible light absorption. Photocatalytic measurements have shown that these materials are only active in UV light due to the Nb to O transition, and that the band gap transition from Cu to Nb is not photocatalytically active, likely due to poor charge carrier mobilities. We have further shown that Cu(II) niobates are photochemically unstable and suffer from reductive photocorrosion. Nevertheless, the herein developed syntheses and thorough characterisation may be of great advantage for further work on these or similar materials for other applications such as for optical applications. The presented detailed XPS analysis of these mixed copper oxidation states could be very helpful for the analysis of other complex copper oxides. coredata.dc:description: Copper niobium oxides have small band gaps and can absorb visible light, making these materials promising for semiconductor photocatalysis. Their chemical stability also greatly surpasses those of the binary copper oxides, which are prone to photocorrosion. Herein, we thoroughly investigate the material system Cu-Nb-O and synthesise up to six different phase-pure and highly crystalline oxides: CuNbO3, CuNb13O33, CuNb3O8, monoclinic and orthorhombic CuNb2O6, and Cu3Nb2O8. Synthesis conditions have been optimised towards easier and more economic syntheses compared to known literature procedures, and all materials were thoroughly analysed with respect to optical and electronic properties and their chemical stability. All materials are utilised in photocatalytic hydrogen evolution, with a heterojunction of monoclinic and orthorhombic CuNb2O6 being the most active one.
coredata.dc:title: Syntheses and characterisation of p-type copper niobium oxides for photocatalytic hydrogen generation
